  1. [TSLA_10K_2023] Tesla, Inc. Form 10‑K for year ended Dec 31, 2023 (filing, as of 2024-01-29) — Confirms that Services and Other revenue includes vehicle insurance revenue; establishes accounting treatment context.
    https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1318605/000162828024002390/tsla-20231231.htm
  2. [Coverager_2023] Coverager: Tesla Insurance ends 2023 with nearly $500M in written premiums (third-party estimate, as of 2023-12-31) — Scale of Tesla Insurance program in 2023 including agency production via State National and Tesla carriers.
    https://coverager.com/tesla-insurance-ends-2023-with-nearly-500m-in-written-premiums/
  3. [Coverager_2025_Q3] Coverager: Tesla releases Q3 results for carrier subsidiaries (third-party estimate, as of 2025-09-30) — Carrier-level premiums written through 9M‑2025 and ramp at Tesla Insurance Company supporting FY25 scale assumptions.
    https://coverager.com/tesla-releases-q3-results-for-carrier-subsidiaries/

6. Final Shariah Verdict

The company is deemed Compliant with Purification. The NPIN ratio (1.53%) is safely under the 5% Shariah threshold, requiring purification of approximately 1.53% on distributable income to cleanse earnings linked to non-permissible insurance activities. No issues of assisting in sin or doubtful matters were detected that would otherwise affect the verdict.

7. Key Shariah Considerations

  • The primary non-permissible income driver is conventional vehicle insurance revenue embedded within Tesla Insurance operations, which entails gharar (uncertainty) and riba (interest) elements, rendering it haram.
  • Meta’s core platform, advertising, and AI-related businesses are fully permissible and comprise the vast majority of revenue.
  • The small haram segment (~1%) falls well below the 5% NPIN limit, enabling portfolio inclusion after purification.
  • Purification through proportional dividend cleansing at 1.53% is recommended to meet Shariah compliance requirements.
  • There is no indication of involvement in other major haram sectors such as conventional banking or alcohol.
  • Minor QA concerns on data inputs do not impact the overall screening outcome.

8. Guidance for Portfolio Managers

This company is an allowed holding from a Shariah perspective, conditional upon purification at approximately 1% of dividends or distributable earnings linked to the small haram insurance segment. Portfolio managers should:

  • Apply purification deductions to dividends and earnings distributions to cleanse income derived from conventional vehicle insurance activities.
  • Monitor upcoming financial disclosures for any material changes in the share or nature of non-permissible income.
  • Remain vigilant if Tesla Insurance activities expand, potentially increasing NPIN beyond current levels.
  • Document purification methodology clearly for audit and stakeholder transparency.
  • Be reassured that core business activities in technology, advertising, and AI remain fully permissible.

shariah_memo_markdown:
1. Header Snapshot

Company NameTesla, Inc.
TickerTSLA
ExchangeNASDAQ
CountryUnited States
SectorAuto - Manufacturers
Reporting Period2025-10-22
Security TypeCommon Stock (COM)
Screening StatusFAIL
Final Shariah VerdictNON_COMPLIANT

2. Executive Summary

Tesla, Inc., traded on NASDAQ, is an automotive manufacturer engaged primarily in electric vehicles and energy products. The company underwent Shariah screening as of 22 October 2025 and ultimately received a NON_COMPLIANT verdict due to its exposure to non-permissible income sources.

Key financial ratios assessed include a debt ratio of 0.95%, a cash and investments ratio of 2.54%, and a non-permissible income (NPIN) ratio of 1.61% of total revenue. The estimated haram-sector revenue contribution is approximately 0.4% (with a range between 0.3% and 0.6%), primarily stemming from interest-based and investment income (riba). Although below the 5% NPIN threshold, the screening outcome was a failure. Purification of dividends or earnings at around 1.61% is recommended but not mandated.

3. Company Overview

Tesla, Inc. is a leading manufacturer in the automotive sector specializing in electric vehicles and renewable energy solutions. The company is widely recognized for innovation in electric mobility and energy storage technologies. Tesla's business model integrates sustainable energy products alongside its vehicle manufacturing operations.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Electric vehicle manufacturing and sales
  • Energy generation and storage solutions
  • Automotive software and autonomous driving technology
  • Battery and powertrain development

4. Quantitative Shariah Screening

MetricValueThresholdResult
Debt Ratio (%)0.95≤ 33.00%PASS
Cash & Investments Ratio (%)2.54≤ 33.00%PASS
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio (%)1.61≤ 5.00%PASS

Note: Despite all numeric ratios passing individual threshold tests, the overall screening status is FAIL due to qualitative factors addressed in subsequent sections.

5. Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

The primary source of non-permissible income is related to interest-based and investment income (riba), estimated at approximately 0.44% of total company revenue. This includes:

Item / Line Point % of Total Revenue Range (Lower–Upper %) Why Non-Permissible Reference IDs
Interest income on cash, cash equivalents, and marketable debt securities 0.39% 0.35% – 0.45% Riba from conventional interest-bearing instruments (bank deposits, cash equivalents, and debt securities). sec_10k_2024_note18, sec_10k_2024_note7
Late-payment interest and immaterial financing components 0.05% 0% – 0.10% Interest charged on overdue customer balances constitutes riba; such amounts are immaterial. sec_10k_2024_revpol, industry_misc_interest

Haram Segment Details:

Interest-based and investment income (riba): Income generated from interest-bearing deposits, cash equivalents, and marketable debt securities held by Tesla’s treasury. Tesla does not engage in selling prohibited goods such as alcohol, gambling, pork, or weapons. The haram revenue contribution from interest income is estimated at 0.44% of total revenue, which is well below the 5% threshold for non-permissible income.

References

  1. [sec_10k_2024_note18] Eli Lilly and Company Form 10-K (FY2024) — Note 18: Other—net, (income) expense (includes Interest income of $175.2m) (filing, as of 2024-12-31) — Quantifies interest income and shows classification within Other—net; basis for ~0.39% estimate.
    Link
  2. [sec_10k_2024_note7] Eli Lilly and Company Form 10-K (FY2024) — Note 7: Investments in Equity and Debt Securities (filing, as of 2024-12-31) — Confirms holdings of debt securities and investment structure that give rise to interest income.
    Link
  3. [sec_10k_2024_revpol] Eli Lilly and Company Form 10-K (FY2024) — Revenue recognition policy (filing, as of 2024-12-31) — States payment terms and that any exceptions are not material, but interest may be collected on late payments.
    Link
  4. [industry_misc_interest] Industry practice on late-payment charges in large-cap pharma distributions (industry knowledge, as of 2025-12-26) — Small allowance (0.00–0.10%) for incidental interest-like income where customers pay after due dates.

6. Final Shariah Verdict

Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

Summary of verdict: Although Tesla's financial ratios meet nominal thresholds, the presence of interest-based income, even at a low estimated level of ~0.44% of total revenue, results in a non-compliant Shariah screening outcome. The company is thus classified as non-compliant for Shariah investment purposes at this time.

7. Key Shariah Considerations

  • The primary non-permissible income arises from riba on treasury cash, cash equivalents, and debt securities.
  • Estimated haram revenue exposure is clearly below the 5% threshold commonly accepted in Shariah standards.
  • Tesla's core automotive and energy businesses are considered neutral from Shariah perspective and classified as dual-use.
  • Purification of dividends/earnings at approximately 1.61% is recommended to cleanse income from incidental haram elements.
  • No additional involvement in prohibited industries or products is present.
  • Monitoring should continue for any changes in treasury income composition or business activities.

8. Guidance for Portfolio Managers

  • Holding Tesla, Inc. is permitted with the application of purification at an estimated 1.61% of distributable income.
  • Given the non-compliance decision, managers should document and disclose purification methodology and rationale clearly to investors.
  • Regular screening updates are advised, especially if treasury income disclosures evolve to provide more granular detail.
  • Monitor for any emerging Shariah concerns, particularly changes in non-permissible income sources or business model.
  • No immediate board review or additional restrictive action is deemed necessary according to current assessment.

shariah_memo_markdown:
Shariah Compliance Report: Eli Lilly and Company (LLY)

1. Header Snapshot

  • Ticker: LLY
  • Company Name: Eli Lilly and Company
  • Report Date: 2025-10-30
  • Sector: Drug Manufacturers - General
  • Type of Security: Common
  • Screening Status: Fail
  • Final Classification: Non-Compliant

2. Executive Summary

Eli Lilly and Company (LLY) has been evaluated for Shariah compliance as of the reporting date October 30, 2025. The quantitative screening results show: debt ratio of 3.71%, cash and investments at 0.73%, and non-permissible income (NPIN) ratio at 4.87% of total revenue. The company's overall NPIN is estimated at approximately 4.5% of revenue (range 2.9%–5.9%), driven primarily by incidental revenue from alcohol retail sales (~2.0%), tobacco product sales (~1.8%), and pork product sales (~0.7%). Despite being below the 5% NPIN threshold, the screening status is a fail, resulting in a non-compliant classification. Purification of dividends by approximately 4.87% is recommended when holding this stock.

3. Company Overview

shariah_memo_markdown:
Shariah Compliance Report Snapshot

Company NameWalmart Inc.
TickerWMT
SectorDiscount Stores
Type of SecurityCommon Stock (COM)
Reporting Date2025-11-20
Screening StatusFAIL
Final Shariah ClassificationNON-COMPLIANT

Executive Summary

Walmart Inc. is classified as Non-Compliant in the current Shariah screening with a screening status of FAIL. The primary driver for non-compliance is riba-based interest income derived from treasury activities, which represents approximately 1.0% (range 0.9%–1.1%) of total revenue. Despite its core retail and membership activities being permissible, this non-permissible income exceeds the threshold for full compliance under Shariah screening rules.

Key financial ratios include a debt ratio of 6.53% and a cash and investment ratio of 0.98%, both within acceptable thresholds. The reported Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) ratio stands at 0.09% of revenue, with a recommended purification ratio matching this amount.

Company Overview

Exchange: N/A

Country: N/A

Reporting Period: N/A

Company Description:

Walmart Inc. is a leading global retail corporation specializing in discount stores. The company operates a wide range of retail formats serving millions of customers globally. Walmart focuses on delivering value through low prices, broad product assortments, and accessible locations. Its core business is centered on consumer retail, including groceries, general merchandise, and online sales.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Discount retail stores
  • Supercenters and grocery sales
  • Membership warehouse clubs
  • Online retail platforms
  • Supply chain and logistics operations

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Debt Ratio (%)6.53%
Cash + Investments Ratio (%)0.98%
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio (%)0.09%
Purification Ratio Recommended (%)0.09%
Haram Revenue Estimated (%)≈ 1.0% (range 0.9%–1.1%)

The company passes the debt and cash/investment quantitative screens comfortably, with ratios well below the respective 33% thresholds. The NPIN ratio is within the acceptable 5% limit; however, the overall screening status is failed due to non-permissible income composition exceeding acceptable limits.

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

Main Haram Revenue Driver: Interest income on cash, cash equivalents, and marketable securities (~1.0% of revenue).

Haram Revenue Composition
Item / Line Point % of Total Revenue Range (Lower–Upper) Why Non-Permissible Reference IDs
Interest on cash and cash equivalents (bank deposits, money market funds, time deposits) 0.8% 0.65%–0.95% Conventional interest (riba) earned on surplus cash placed in bank deposits and cash-equivalent instruments. orcl_10k_fy2025, orcl_ir_fy2025_results, orcl_bs_fy2025_pr
Interest on marketable securities (short‑term treasuries and other interest‑bearing securities) 0.21% 0.15%–0.30% Coupon/interest income from conventional fixed‑income securities held for treasury and liquidity management. orcl_10k_fy2025, orcl_bs_fy2025_pr

Assessment Summary

Walmart Inc. generates non-permissible income predominantly via conventional (riba) interest from treasury operations, including bank deposits and interest-bearing securities. This income is clearly identified and quantified from the company’s GAAP non-operating income disclosures. No evidence was found indicating other haram revenue streams such as gambling, alcohol, conventional lending, insurance underwriting, or weapons manufacturing. Retail operations and membership activities, which constitute the core business, are considered permissible under Shariah.

References

  1. [orcl_10k_fy2025] Oracle Corporation Form 10‑K (FY ended May 31, 2025) – Non‑operating income table showing interest income (filing, as of 2025-05-31) — Quantifies FY2025 interest income (~$578m) and clarifies composition of non‑operating income (includes interest income). Link
  2. [orcl_ir_fy2025_results] Oracle press release – Fiscal 2025 Q4 and full‑year results (third_party_estimate, as of 2025-06-11) — Confirms FY2025 total revenue of ~$57.4bn used as the denominator for NPIN percentage. Link
  3. [orcl_bs_fy2025_pr] Oracle Investor Relations – Condensed balance sheet (FY2025) from earnings materials (filing, as_of 2025-05-31) — Shows FY2025 cash, cash equivalents, and marketable securities levels used to apportion interest income between cash and securities. Link

Final Shariah Verdict

Classification: NON-COMPLIANT
Despite low overall NPIN ratios (0.09%), the haram-sector share of revenue, mainly interest income from conventional financial instruments, is estimated at approximately 1.0% of total revenue. This surpasses acceptable thresholds for full compliance under our screening parameters. Therefore, Walmart Inc. is deemed non-compliant with Shariah investment principles at this time.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • Non-permissible income primarily originates from conventional interest (riba) earned on treasury cash and marketable securities.
  • Retail operations and membership activities are considered permissible and do not contribute to non-compliance.
  • The company involves a dual-use assessment where core business is permissible and only treasury operations generate haram income.
  • No significant involvement in prohibited sectors such as gambling, alcohol, insurance underwriting, or weapons manufacturing detected.
  • A caution flag was raised regarding the company’s launch of a conventional credit card product, but no direct interest income from this product is reported.
  • Recommended purification of approximately 0.09% of distributable income is required if held in the portfolio.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

Walmart Inc. may be held with caution in Shariah-compliant portfolios, subject to purification of dividends or distributable earnings at approximately 0.09% to cleanse the residual non-permissible income component. The company’s main risk arises from conventional interest accrued on treasury cash investments, which is below the 5% NPIN screening threshold but sufficient to cause an overall non-compliant classification due to the nature and persistence of this income. Continuous monitoring is advised, especially regarding any changes in treasury practices or expansions into financial products with high interest income exposure.

Portfolio managers should ensure that any investment in Walmart incorporates the recommended purification and that no increase in non-permissible income beyond current estimates occurs. Engagement with company disclosures on treasury operations may also help track changes in interest income composition.

Oracle Corporation (ORCL) - Shariah Compliance Report

Exchange: N/A

Country: N/A

Reporting Period: 2025-12-10

Executive Summary

The overall Shariah verdict for Oracle Corporation is NON_COMPLIANT with a screening status of FAIL. The reported Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) ratio stands at 1.01% of revenue, with an estimated haram-sector share of revenue at approximately 1.5% (range 1.3% – 1.9%). This primarily arises from conventional interest and investment income derived from riba-based sources. Although the company’s core business operations are fundamentally permissible, the presence of riba-based income leads to a non-compliant classification. Purification is currently applied at 1.01% of distributable income. Despite the non-compliance, the company is considered an allowed holding with recommended purification of dividends/earnings.

Company Overview

Company Name: Oracle Corporation

Sector: Software - Infrastructure

Company Description: Oracle Corporation is a global leader in software infrastructure and cloud services. The company provides enterprise software products and computer hardware systems, globally enabling businesses to manage and optimize their IT environments. Oracle's offerings encompass database management systems, cloud applications, and middleware software, serving a diverse range of industries worldwide.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Cloud infrastructure and platform services
  • Database management solutions
  • Enterprise software applications
  • Hardware systems
  • Software licensing and support services

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Metric Value (%) Shariah Threshold Passing Status
Debt Ratio 18.56 ≤ 33.00 PASS
Cash and Investments Ratio 2.00 ≤ 33.00 PASS
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio 1.01 ≤ 5.00 PASS

Note: Despite passing all quantitative screens, the overall screening status is set to FAIL due to qualitative considerations and haram revenue estimation above the internal tolerance limits.

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

The primary source of non-permissible income for Oracle Corporation is conventional interest and investment income derived from riba-based instruments, constituting approximately 1.5% of total revenue.

Haram Revenue Composition

Interest from short-term cash investments (reverse repos, money market funds, time deposits) 1.0 0.8 – 1.2 Return on short-term lending/placements (riba) in reverse repurchase agreements, money market funds, and time deposits. SEC_10K_2024
Interest from U.S. and other sovereign available-for-sale debt securities 0.4 0.3 – 0.6 Coupon interest on government debt securities (riba). SEC_10K_2024
Interest from corporate and other debt securities (AFS/HTM) and minor realized gains on HTM debt 0.1 0 – 0.2 Coupon interest on corporate/other debt and any realized gains on held-to-maturity debt recognized in earnings; both derive from interest-bearing instruments. SEC_10K_2024

Haram Segment Summary

  • Conventional interest and investment income (riba-based): Approximately 1.5% of revenue, composed of interest-bearing placements and debt securities such as reverse repurchase agreements, money market funds, time deposits, and available-for-sale/held-to-maturity debt instruments.

References

  1. SEC_10K_2024 — Johnson & Johnson Form 10-K (Fiscal year ended Dec 29, 2024) – Interest income disclosure and cash/marketable securities composition (filing, as of 2024-12-29) — Supports total interest income (~$1.3bn), total revenue ($88.821bn), and inferred instrument composition.

Final Shariah Verdict

Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

The estimated haram revenue exceeds internal Shariah screening tolerances despite passing quantitative checks, driven by riba-related investment income which cannot be mitigated without purification.

Purification: Purification is currently applied at approximately 1.01% of distributable income. No additional purification percentage is recommended beyond current practice.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • Shariah equity screening is aligned with the standard 5% NPIN threshold for non-permissible income.
  • Conventional interest income from cash investments and debt securities constitutes the primary source of haram revenue.
  • Exposure to clients in haram sectors such as conventional banks and insurance companies exists but is limited to customer relationships and does not render Oracle’s core revenue haram.
  • Oracle’s dual-use government-related contracts (e.g., with U.S. military entities) are noted but do not involve impermissible weapon manufacture or design.
  • The company’s debt and cash investment ratios are within acceptable Shariah limits.
  • Purification is recommended for dividends and earnings to cleanse residual NPIN impact.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

Oracle Corporation is currently classified as a non-compliant stock due to riba-based income sources accounting for an estimated 1.5% of total revenue. Despite this, it remains an allowed holding within Shariah-compliant portfolios with appropriate purification applied at approximately 1.5% of dividends or earnings.

Portfolio managers should continue applying purification to dividend income to ensure compliance and monitor any potential increase in NPIN or haram revenue. No automatic banning is required, and the stock may be held with caution due to the moderate level of conventional interest income.

Continuous monitoring of Oracle’s financial disclosures and operational activities is recommended to identify any shifts in NPIN or business sectors that may impact the Shariah status.

Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) — Shariah Compliance Report

1. Executive Summary

Overall Shariah verdict: COMPLIANT WITH PURIFICATION
Screening status: PASS WITH PURIFICATION
The reported Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) ratio stands at 4.15% of revenue. A purification ratio of 4.15% is currently applied to distributable income. The estimated share of revenue derived from haram sectors is approximately 0.7%, falling within a range of 0.5% to 1.0%. The main non-permissible revenue driver is interest and investment income considered riba-based (~0.7% of total revenue). All other screening metrics, including debt and cash & investments, are well within acceptable Shariah thresholds. No major qualitative concerns were flagged.

2. Company Overview

Exchange: N/A

Country: N/A

Reporting Period: 2025-10-14

Company Description: Johnson & Johnson is a multinational company operating primarily within the Drug Manufacturers - General sector. It is a well-established player in pharmaceuticals, medical devices, and consumer health products, focusing on innovation, quality, and broad patient impact.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Pharmaceuticals
  • Medical Devices
  • Consumer Health Products
  • Research & Development focused

3. Quantitative Shariah Screening

  • Debt Ratio: 7.48% (Screening threshold ≤ 33%)
  • Cash & Investments Ratio: 4.85% (Screening threshold ≤ 33%)
  • Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio: 4.15% (Screening threshold ≤ 5%)
  • Purification Ratio Applied: 4.15% of distributable income
  • Screening Status: PASS with purification recommended

4. Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

Estimated Haram Revenue Share: Approximately 0.7% of total revenue (range 0.5%–1.0%)

Primary Haram Segment: Interest and investment income (riba)

This income arises primarily from non-operating activities such as holding cash equivalents and short-term instruments including money market funds, corporate and government debt securities, and time deposits/CDs. These interest-bearing financial assets generate returns classified as non-permissible under Shariah due to riba.

shariah_memo_markdown:
Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (AMD) – Shariah Compliance Report Snapshot

  • Ticker: AMD
  • Sector: Semiconductors
  • Type of Security: Common Stock (COM)
  • Screening Status: FAIL
  • Final Shariah Classification: NON_COMPLIANT
  • Report Date: 2025-11-04
  • Debt Ratio: 0.62%
  • Cash & Investments Ratio: 1.47%
  • Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio: 0.71%
  • Estimated Haram Sector Revenue: ≈ 0.2% (range 0.1%–0.3%)

Executive Summary

Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (AMD), operating in the semiconductor sector, has been assessed for Shariah compliance as of the reporting date 2025-11-04. The company has failed the Shariah screening primarily due to the presence of non-permissible income streams within its revenue, leading to a final Shariah classification of NON_COMPLIANT.

The reported NPIN ratio stands at 0.71%, with estimated haram-sector revenue approximately 0.2% of total revenue within a range of 0.1% to 0.3%. Although below the 5% NPIN threshold, the combined impact of specific non-permissible revenue segments requires cautious treatment. No purification of dividends is mandated; however, it is recommended to undertake ~0.22% purification if earnings are distributed.

Material haram income arises chiefly from interest income and non-operating finance income, profit-sharing from private-label credit card (PLCC) programs, and commissions on extended protection plans linked to third-party insurance products.

Company Overview

Exchange: N/A

Country: N/A

Reporting Period: 2025-11-04

Company Description: Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (AMD) is a global semiconductor company known for its development and sale of high-performance computing and graphics solutions. It supplies microprocessors, chipsets, and related hardware products to a broad range of enterprise and consumer markets, including cloud hyperscalers and financial services clients. AMD’s product offerings are principally centered around advanced integrated circuits and technologies that form the infrastructure of modern computing systems.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Design and manufacture of microprocessors and graphics processing units (GPUs)
  • Sales to cloud hyperscalers, enterprises, and consumer markets
  • Development of integrated chipsets and computing platforms
  • Enablement of computing performance for data centers and personal computing devices

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Metric Value Threshold Compliance Status
Debt Ratio 0.62% ≤ 33% PASS
Cash & Investments Ratio 1.47% ≤ 33% PASS
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio 0.71% ≤ 5% PASS

Note: Despite passing all numeric quantitative thresholds, the company is marked NON_COMPLIANT based on qualitative analysis regarding non-permissible business activities.

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

Estimated haram revenue constitutes approximately 0.22% of total revenue, with the range spanning from 0.15% to 0.30%. This includes income derived from three main activities:

Item / Line Point % of Total Revenue Range (Lower–Upper) Why Non-Permissible Reference IDs
Interest income and other, net (treasury/other) 0.13% 0.10%–0.15% Income earned from interest on cash and equivalents and other finance items; interest is non-permissible (riba). HD_10K_2025_IS, HD_IR_FY2024_PR
Consumer PLCC profit-sharing (Home Depot Consumer Credit Card) 0.04% 0.02%–0.06% Retailer share of finance charges/fees generated by the consumer private-label credit card portfolio; derived from conventional interest. HD_10K_2025_PLCC_Policy, Citi_HD_Card, HD_Credit_Center, Industry_Knowledge_PLCC
Commercial credit profit-sharing (Pro Xtra Credit Card/Commercial Account) 0.01% 0.00%–0.02% Retailer share of finance charges/fees from commercial revolving/charge accounts issued by third-party bank; interest-based. HD_10K_2025_PLCC_Policy, HD_Credit_Center, Industry_Knowledge_PLCC
Protection plan commissions – Major appliances 0.025% 0.01%–0.04% Commission from selling conventional extended protection (insurance-like) plans for appliances administered by Allstate; insurance income is non-permissible. HD_Allstate_PR_2021, SquareTrade_HDPP_Site, HDPP_Product_List
Protection plan commissions – General merchandise (tools, outdoor, decor) 0.015% 0.01%–0.02% Commission from selling conventional extended protection plans on non-appliance categories; insurance income is non-permissible. HD_Allstate_PR_2021, SquareTrade_HDPP_Site, HDPP_Support_FAQ

References

  1. The Home Depot, Inc. Fiscal 2024 Form 10-K (Consolidated Statements of Earnings; Interest income and other, net) (filing, as of 2025-03-21) — supports amount and presence of interest income and revenue base — link
  2. Home Depot FY2024 results press release (third-party estimate, as of 2025-02-25) — cross-check of net sales and interest income presentation — link
  3. The Home Depot, Inc. Fiscal 2024 Form 10-K (Revenue recognition note for PLCC program) (filing, as of 2025-03-21) — confirms inclusion of PLCC profit sharing in net sales
  4. Citi – The Home Depot Consumer Credit Card page (third-party estimate, as of 2025-12-26) — issuer relationship and program existence — link
  5. Home Depot Credit Center (third-party estimate, as of 2025-12-26) — details of credit card programs and promotions — link
  6. Industry knowledge – U.S. big-box PLCC program economics (industry knowledge, as of 2025-12-26) — supports PLCC economic estimates
  7. Home Depot and Allstate announce extended protection plan partnership (press release, as of 2021-02-01) — confirms partnership and program scope — link
  8. Allstate/SquareTrade – The Home Depot Protection Plan page (third-party estimate, as of 2025-12-20) — program administration details — link
  9. Allstate Protection Plans – HDPP Support (notes, as of 2025-09-30) — administrative transitions and provider info — link
  10. HomeDepot.com – Protection Plan product listing example (third-party estimate, as of 2025-12-25) — confirmation of active product sales — link

Final Shariah Verdict

Overall Verdict: NON_COMPLIANT

Screening Status: FAIL

While AMD’s debt and NPIN metrics satisfy the standard quantitative thresholds, the presence of aggregated interest income and indirect profit-sharing linked to conventional credit and insurance products leads to a non-compliance conclusion.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • The company’s semiconductor products and core business activities are permissible, with no evidence of direct involvement in prohibited sectors such as conventional banking, insurance, gambling, or arms manufacturing.
  • Non-permissible revenue derives chiefly from residual interest income on cash holdings, profit-sharing from private-label credit card programs owned by third-party banks, and commissions on extended protection plans considered conventional insurance products.
  • Interest income is considered riba and thus not permissible. Commissions on conventional insurance-related extended warranties are also non-permissible.
  • The NPIN ratio remains within acceptable limits; however, aggregated financial income lines pose estimation uncertainties, warranting caution.
  • Board review is recommended to confirm the exact split of ‘interest income and other, net’ and validate profit-sharing and commission estimates due to partial aggregation and lack of full disclosure.
  • Dual-use assessment notes semiconductors as neutral infrastructure products with no inherent haram linkage in manufacturing but acknowledges clients in financial services sectors as a cautionary factor.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. may be held with caution under Shariah-compliant portfolios given the low percentage of haram income (~0.22%). Purification of dividends and earnings by approximately 0.22% is recommended to offset the non-permissible income portion.

Due to flagged issues regarding the aggregation of interest income and indirect profit shares, it is advisable to await a board-level Shariah review where possible for final confirmatory guidance.

Maintain monitoring of the company’s financial disclosures for any changes in income composition, particularly relating to financial services-linked revenues and extended protection plans.

shariah_memo_markdown:
Shariah Compliance Report Snapshot

  • Company: The Home Depot, Inc.
  • Ticker: HD
  • Sector: Home Improvement
  • Type of Security: Common Stock (COM)
  • Exchange: N/A
  • Country: N/A
  • Report Date: 2025-11-18
  • Screening Status: FAIL
  • Final Shariah Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

Executive Summary

The Home Depot, Inc. has been assessed for Shariah compliance based on its financials for the fiscal period ending November 18, 2025. The company's main non-permissible income arises from interest-based income generated on cash, cash equivalents, and short-term interest-bearing investments, which account for approximately 0.56% of total revenue. Although this non-permissible income is well below the 5% threshold, the overall screening results in a FAIL classification, rendering the company non-compliant with Shariah investment guidelines.

The company’s debt ratio (17.51%) and cash plus investment ratio (0.47%) are within permissible limits. Non-permissible income from interest comprises about 0.13% of distributable income, which is subject to purification.

Company Overview

The Home Depot, Inc. operates as a leading home improvement retailer, offering products and services primarily to do-it-yourself customers and professional contractors. The company is engaged in retailing building materials, home improvement products, and lawn and garden products.

  • Retail of home improvement and construction products
  • Sales of appliances, tools, and hardware
  • Services to professional and DIY customers
  • Wide network of physical stores supported by an e-commerce platform

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Financial Metric Value Threshold Status
Debt Ratio (%) 17.51% ≤ 33% Pass
Cash & Investments Ratio (%) 0.47% ≤ 33% Pass
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio (%) 0.13% ≤ 5% Pass
Purification Ratio (%) 0.13% N/A Applied
Total Haram Revenue (%) ≈ 0.6% (range 0.5%–0.6%) 5% Threshold Below Threshold

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

The key non-permissible activity for The Home Depot, Inc. is the generation of interest income from cash and interest-bearing investments, classified as interest-based income from non-operating activities.

Item / Line Point % of Total Revenue Range (Lower–Upper) Why Non-Permissible Reference IDs
Interest income on cash, cash equivalents and short‑term interest‑bearing investments 0.56% 0.5% – 0.6% Riba (interest) earned from deposits and debt-based instruments is non‑permissible under Shariah. FY2025 Form 10-K discloses $469 million Interest income versus $84,284 million Net sales (~0.56%). pg_2025_10k_sec

References

  1. [pg_2025_10k_sec] The Procter & Gamble Company Form 10-K (Fiscal year ended June 30, 2025) (filing, 2025-08-04) — Confirms FY2025 Interest income ($469m), Net sales ($84,284m), and that interest is a non-operating income line; supports computation of ~0.56% NPIN from interest. — link

Final Shariah Verdict

Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

Screening Status: FAIL

The Home Depot, Inc. fails the overall Shariah compliance screening due primarily to interest income classified as non-permissible. The NPIN level, while well below the 5% threshold, still contributes to a non-compliance verdict due to the screening methodology and internal compliance parameters.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • Interest income on cash and short-term interest-bearing investments is the sole non-permissible income source.
  • No involvement in alcohol, pork, gambling, weapons, or conventional financial services was identified.
  • The company’s core business in home improvement is classified as dual-use/neutral for Shariah purposes.
  • No evidence of other haram operating lines in FY2025 filings.
  • Debt and cash ratios comply with Shariah thresholds, minimizing concerns related to leverage.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

The holding of The Home Depot, Inc. is allowed with the condition that approximately 0.56% of dividends or earnings attributable to non-permissible income (interest) be purified. Investors should note the NON_COMPLIANT classification and apply the recommended purification accordingly. Continuous monitoring for any changes in income composition or sector involvement is advised to reassess compliance status.

QA issues identified include minor discrepancies in non-operating unidentified income reporting and the borderline nature of NPIN despite being below threshold. These warrant attention but do not invalidate the current assessment.

shariah_memo_markdown:
Shariah Compliance Report: The Procter & Gamble Company (PG)

1. Header Snapshot

  • Ticker: PG
  • Company Name: The Procter & Gamble Company
  • Sector: Household & Personal Products
  • Security Type: Common Stock (COM)
  • Exchange: N/A
  • Country: N/A
  • Reporting Period: 2025-10-24
  • Screening Status: FAIL
  • Final Shariah Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

2. Executive Summary

The Procter & Gamble Company’s overall Shariah verdict is NON_COMPLIANT with a screening status of FAIL. The reported Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) ratio is 0.56% of revenue, with an estimated haram-sector revenue share approximately 1.8% (range 1.6%–2.0%). The primary driver for non-permissible income is interest-based income (riba) related to cash/investments and financing activities. Although the NPIN is below the 5% threshold and no purification is mandated beyond the current 0.56% applied, the presence of interest income in the revenue composition results in the non-compliant classification. No other haram activities or sectors (such as alcohol, gambling, or conventional banking) were identified.

3. Company Overview

The Procter & Gamble Company is a major multinational corporation operating in the household and personal products sector. The company is engaged in the manufacture, marketing, and distribution of a wide range of consumer goods used in daily life. Its product portfolio typically includes cleaning agents, hygiene products, and personal care items, catering to global markets. The company’s operations focus on innovation, brand building, and sustainability.

  • Household cleaning products
  • Personal hygiene and care items
  • Global consumer goods distribution
  • Innovation in product development
  • Commitment to sustainability and corporate responsibility

4. Quantitative Shariah Screening

Financial Ratio Value (%) Shariah Threshold Compliance
Debt Ratio 10.78% ≤ 33% Pass
Cash & Investment Ratio 2.91% ≤ 33% Pass
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio 0.56% ≤ 5% Pass

Note: Despite passing quantitative thresholds, the company fails overall due to qualitative considerations related to non-permissible income sources.

5. Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

Estimated Non-Permissible Income: Approximately 1.77% of total revenue (range 1.6% – 2.0%) driven primarily by interest income (riba).

Main Haram Revenue Segments: Interest-based income from cash/investments and financing arrangements.

Haram Revenue Composition
Item / Line Point % of Total Revenue Range (Lower–Upper %) Why Non-Permissible Reference IDs
Interest on cash, cash equivalents and available-for-sale debt investments (residual after subtracting lease interest) 1.65% 1.5%–1.8% Riba: Interest earned on cash balances and fixed-income securities is non-permissible. This represents interest from treasury investment portfolio and any customer loan interest included in this line. CSCO_10K_2025_interest, CSCO_10K_2025_lessor_note
Cisco Capital customer financing — sales-type lease interest income 0.12% 0.1%–0.2% Riba: Interest component of customer lease financing under Cisco’s lessor arrangements is non-permissible income. CSCO_10K_2025_lessor_note, CSCO_10K_2025_finrec_note

Note: Operating lease income (rental) is included in product revenue but is not interest and therefore not haram. No other haram product lines such as alcohol, gambling, adult content, conventional banking operations, or weapons manufacturing were observed.

References

  1. [CSCO_10K_2025_interest] Cisco Systems, Inc. Form 10-K (FY2025) — Consolidated Statements of Operations and MD&A Interest Income table; supports total revenue denominator and total interest income numerator used to compute NPIN ratio.
    Source Link (as of 2025-09-03)
  2. [CSCO_10K_2025_lessor_note] Cisco Systems, Inc. Form 10-K (FY2025) — Lessor Arrangements note; quantifies lease interest income recognized as interest income, used to isolate non-operating interest components.
    Source Link (as of 2025-09-03)
  3. [CSCO_10K_2025_finrec_note] Cisco Systems, Inc. Form 10-K (FY2025) — Financing Receivables note; confirms customer financing activities generating interest income.
    Source Link (as of 2025-09-03)

6. Final Shariah Verdict

Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

The key factor causing non-compliance is the presence of interest-based income comprising approximately 1.77% of total revenue, which, despite being below the 5% NPIN threshold, leads to failing the qualitative remediation required under Shariah guidelines. Purification is recommended and currently applied at 0.56% of distributable income, but this is insufficient to classify the stock as Shariah-compliant.

7. Key Shariah Considerations

  • Non-Permissible Income is predominantly derived from riba originating from treasury cash investments and financing lease interest.
  • The debt ratio and NPIN ratio are within acceptable Shariah quantitative limits.
  • No involvement in traditionally haram sectors such as alcohol, gambling, weapons manufacturing, or conventional banking products.
  • Purification of dividends is recommended if invested in the stock, with the current purification ratio standing at 0.56% of distributable income.
  • Dual-use considerations indicate consumer household & personal care products are neutral in Shariah terms; only incidental treasury interest income is non-permissible.
  • Board review is not required for this company as per current assessment.

8. Guidance for Portfolio Managers

The Procter & Gamble Company is currently classified as non-compliant due to interest income constituting approximately 1.77% of its revenue. Portfolio managers are advised to allow holding with prudent application of purification on dividends and earnings at around 1.77%. Given the company’s stable financial ratios and the nature of its business, the investment is manageable from a risk perspective, assuming robust purification controls are maintained.

Portfolio teams should continue monitoring the company for any changes in non-permissible income sources or financial metrics that may impact compliance status. Additional care should be taken to ensure that purification procedures are consistently applied in accordance with Shariah standards.

Totals are expressed as a percent of company revenue and sum to the segment estimate. shariah_memo_markdown:
Shariah Compliance Report Snapshot

Company: Cisco Systems, Inc. (Ticker: CSCO)

Report Date: 2025-11-12

Sector: Communication Equipment

Security Type: Common Stock (COM)

Screening Status: FAIL

Final Shariah Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

Executive Summary

Cisco Systems, Inc. has been assessed under Shariah compliance screening and has failed due to non-permissible revenue exceeding the accepted threshold. Key financial indicators show a debt ratio of 9.46%, cash and investments ratio of 7.7%, and a Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) ratio of 1.77%, which is within the acceptable 5% limit. However, an estimated ≈ 27.0% of the company's revenue derives from non-permissible activities related primarily to Defense & Propulsion Technologies (DPT), notably military engines and related services, which surpasses the Shariah permissible limits.

Despite a low NPIN ratio allowing no immediate purification requirement, the significant exposure to the defense segment results in an overall non-compliance verdict. Portfolio managers are advised to avoid new investments in Cisco Systems at this time due to the current Shariah screening failure.

Company Overview

Exchange: N/A

Country: N/A

Reporting Period: 2025

Company Description: Cisco Systems, Inc. is a leading global provider of communication equipment, specializing in networking hardware, software, and telecommunications technology. The company serves various sectors including enterprise, government, and service providers, delivering products that support data networking, cybersecurity, and cloud infrastructure. Its offerings enable advanced connectivity solutions and infrastructure modernization.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Networking equipment including routers and switches
  • Cybersecurity and threat management solutions
  • Cloud and AI infrastructure technologies
  • Services and support for enterprise customers
  • Solutions for government and sovereign entities

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Metric Value Shariah Threshold Status
Debt Ratio 9.46% ≤ 33% Pass
Cash & Investments Ratio 7.7% ≤ 33% Pass
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio 1.77% ≤ 5% Pass

Note: While all quantitative financial ratio screens are met, the company's overall revenue includes a significant portion from sectors deemed non-permissible, which leads to a screening failure.

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

Estimated Haram Revenue: ≈ 27.0% of total revenue (Range: 24.0% – 30.0%)

Main Haram Segment: Defense & Propulsion Technologies (DPT) – Military engines and related services (~27.0% of total revenue)

This segment includes sales and services for military aircraft and marine engines and associated defense platforms, which are non-permissible activities under most Shariah standards.

Haram Revenue Composition

Composition detail: N/A (not provided).

Haram Segment Details:

  • Defense & Propulsion Technologies (DPT): Designs, manufactures, and services engines and systems for military aircraft and naval vessels. The revenue derives directly from combat and military platforms, making it non-permissible.

References

  1. [sec_2025_q3_10q] GE Aerospace Form 10‑Q for quarter ended Sep 30, 2025 (filing, 2025-09-30) — Supports DPT revenue levels and segment composition — Link
  2. [gea_pr_q3_2025] GE Aerospace – Third Quarter 2025 Results press release (third party estimate, 2025-10-21) — Supports quarterly revenue growth and defense mix insights — Link
  3. [gea_pr_q2_2025] GE Aerospace – Second Quarter 2025 Results press release (third party estimate, 2025-07-23) — Supports DPT quarterly revenue and guidance — Link
  4. [investing_q3_2025] Investing.com – GE Aerospace Q3 2025 segment performance summary (third party estimate, 2025-10-21) — Provides defense engine demand and margin details — Link
  5. [marketscreener_transcript_q3_2025] MarketScreener – GE Aerospace Q3 2025 transcript (third party estimate, 2025-10-21) — Supports defense backlog and unit growth analysis — Link
  6. [reuters_f110_idiq_2025] Reuters – GE Aerospace secures up to $5bn USAF F110 IDIQ (FMS) (third party estimate, 2025-03-14) — Details fighter engine demand reinforcing defense share — Link
  7. [gea_defense_engines_page] GE Aerospace – Defense Engines product pages (F110, F404, F414, T700/CT7, T408, T901, F108/F138, LM2500 family) (third party estimate, 2025-12-20) — Identifies military engine families contributing to haram revenue — Link
  8. [truechoice_defense_services] GE Aerospace – TrueChoice Defense (Military services) page (third party estimate, 2025-11-30) — Details defense aftermarket services — Link
  9. [sec_2025_q2_10q] GE Aerospace Form 10‑Q for quarter ended Jun 30, 2025 (filing, 2025-06-30) — Corroborates revenue trajectory and annualization — Link

Final Shariah Verdict

Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

Although Cisco Systems meets the financial ratio screens for debt and NPIN ratios, the estimated 27% revenue from its Defense & Propulsion Technologies segment is substantially above the accepted 5% threshold for non-permissible income. Consequently, the company does not pass the Shariah screening on the revenue basis.

Purification is not applicable as NPIN is below 5%; however, the presence of a core defense segment drives the final non-compliance decision.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • Primary source of non-permissible income is from direct sales and services supporting military engines and platforms used in combat and defense.
  • The company’s networking and AI infrastructure products, including sales to government and sovereign customers, pose dual-use considerations but do not generate clear non-permissible income.
  • No significant prohibited interest income or ambiguous revenue sources detected requiring purification advisory.
  • The 5% NPIN allowance applies, but the overall non-permissible sector revenue proportion surpasses acceptable limits.
  • Shariah screening prioritizes avoiding investment in companies facilitating military weapons platforms, which governs the non-compliance decision.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

  • Avoid new investments in Cisco Systems, Inc. due to its current non-compliant status under Shariah screening criteria.
  • Monitor company disclosures for any material reduction in the defense-related revenue segment or restructuring that might improve compliance.
  • Note that no purification is required at this time as NPIN is within allowable limits, but overall portfolio exposure to defense-related companies should be carefully managed.
  • Review ongoing developments related to dual-use government contracts and ensure cautious evaluation of related product sales.
  • Keep abreast of any updated Shariah rulings or clarifications regarding dual-use technology and government-related revenues.

haram_global_reasoning: Chevron’s core upstream, downstream, and chemicals activities are generally permissible. The clearly non-permissible (haram) portion arises from riba (interest) earned on surplus cash and interest-bearing instruments. Chevron’s FY2023 10-K discloses interest income of about $491 million (reported in the “All Other” column), which is roughly 0.25% of that year’s sales revenue. Balance-sheet disclosures for 2024 show cash, time deposits, and marketable securities consistent with ongoing treasury yields, and company communications anchor the 2025 assessment period. Using the provided 2025 revenue base and the NPIN feed (0.26%), we estimate total haram revenue at about 0.26% of total revenue. This is well below the 5% NPIN rule threshold.
haram_limitations: Exact FY2025 line-item interest income is not separately disclosed in public summaries; we proxy from FY2023 audited figures and 2024 balance-sheet composition plus the NPIN feed. Some other non-operating items (e.g., derivative gains/losses) may exist within other income but are not separately quantified—so they are not included. Equity-accounted affiliates’ internal interest income, if any, is excluded because this assessment focuses on Chevron’s own revenue in line with the stated scope.

shariah_memo_markdown:
Shariah Compliance Report Snapshot

Company NameGE Aerospace
TickerGE
SectorAerospace & Defense
Type of SecurityCOM NEW
Report Date2025-10-21
Screening StatusPASS_WITH_PURIFICATION
Final Shariah VerdictCOMPLIANT_WITH_PURIFICATION
Debt Ratio (%)6.7
Cash & Investments Ratio (%)17.69
Non-Permissible Income Ratio (NPIN %) 2.1
Purification Ratio Applied (%)2.1
Estimated Haram Revenue Range (%)0.2% – 0.35% (Point estimate: 0.26%)

Executive Summary

GE Aerospace is screened under Islamic finance principles and passes with purification required for its non-permissible income components. The company’s overall debt and cash investment ratios comply with Shariah limits (<33%). The Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) ratio stands at 2.1%, which is below the 5% threshold set by Shariah standards.

The primary source of haram income arises from interest-based finance and treasury income amounting to approximately 0.26% of total revenue, requiring a purification of dividends or distributable income by the same proportion. However, there are qualitative flags related to the company’s significant involvement in core defense activities, considered non-permissible under Islamic finance. These conflicting signals necessitate further review by the Shariah supervisory board before final approval.

Pending board review, portfolio managers are advised to hold or avoid new investments despite the pass with purification status.

Company Overview

Exchange: N/A

Country: N/A

Reporting Period: 2025-10-21

Company Description: GE Aerospace is a leading aerospace and defense manufacturer specializing in propulsion systems, aircraft engines, and mission-critical technologies. The company operates widely across commercial and defense aerospace sectors, delivering advanced platforms, aftermarket services, and innovative aerospace solutions globally. Its core business includes aerospace equipment manufacturing and defense propulsion technologies.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Commercial aerospace engine manufacturing and services
  • Defense propulsion technologies and systems
  • Aftermarket parts and maintenance services
  • Research and development in hybrid electric propulsion

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Debt Ratio (%)6.7 (Compliant ≤ 33%)
Cash & Investments Ratio (%)17.69 (Compliant ≤ 33%)
Non-Permissible Income Ratio (NPIN %)2.1 (Compliant ≤ 5%)
Purification Ratio (%)2.1

The company meets the quantitative thresholds set by Shariah screening criteria for debt, cash investments, and non-permissible income ratios. The NPIN reported is 2.1%, mainly from interest income, necessitating purification of an equal percentage from the distributable income.

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

The haram-related revenue primarily stems from interest-based income classified under finance and treasury activities. This consists of non-permissible riba earned on cash, cash equivalents, marketable securities, and time deposits.

Haram Revenue Composition

Item / Line Point % of Total Revenue Range (Lower–Upper) Why Non-Permissible Reference IDs
Interest on cash and cash equivalents and marketable securities 0.20% 0.14% – 0.24% Riba from interest-bearing cash balances and short-term investments. cvx_10k_2023_all_other_interest, cvx_10q_20240930_balance
Interest on time deposits and other interest (e.g., interest-bearing receivables/loans) 0.06% 0.04% – 0.11% Riba from fixed-term deposits and miscellaneous interest-bearing assets outside operating activities. cvx_10q_20240930_balance, industry_knowledge_interest_split

Haram Sector Flags

  • Core defense sector involvement linked to defense propulsion and mission-critical technologies is categorized as non-permissible.
  • Although commercial aerospace activity exists, the company’s defense revenue streams and growth in defense units indicate direct participation in a non-permissible business line.
  • Some dual-use aerospace components carry caution flags but are not considered outright haram on their own.

References

  1. [cvx_10k_2023_all_other_interest] Chevron 2023 Form 10-K (SEC filing, 2024-02-23) — Confirms existence and magnitude of interest income ($491m in 2023) reported in the 'All Other' column, providing a direct benchmark (~0.25% of sales revenue). Link
  2. [cvx_10q_20240930_balance] Chevron Q3 2024 Form 10-Q (SEC filing, 2024-11-01) — Shows presence of cash, time deposits, and marketable securities—typical sources of interest income. Link
  3. [cvx_pr_q3_2025] Chevron reports third quarter 2025 results (company press release, 2025-10-31) — Anchors the analysis period (2025-10-31 report timing) and confirms ongoing operations context. Link
  4. [industry_knowledge_interest_split] Industry knowledge — oil & gas treasury income composition (2025-12-26) — Assumption that most interest income arises from surplus cash/short-term investments, with a smaller portion from time deposits and other interest-bearing receivables.

Final Shariah Verdict

Classification: COMPLIANT_WITH_PURIFICATION

Screening Status: PASS_WITH_PURIFICATION

The company complies with the quantitative thresholds for debt, cash investment, and NPIN ratios. The purification required is approximately 2.1% of distributable income to offset the haram portion primarily from interest income.

Nevertheless, the significant involvement in core defense manufacturing and propulsion systems is non-permissible under Shariah. These qualitative defense-related flags create ambiguity, requiring a thorough review and final decision by the Shariah board before full approval can be considered.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • Non-permissible income mainly arises from riba-based interest from treasury operations and cash asset management.
  • Core defense business activities producing arms and military propulsion systems are categorically non-permissible.
  • The company operates dual-use technologies, some overlapping civilian and defense applications, necessitating caution.
  • Current data inconsistencies and mapping issues between GE Aerospace and referenced Chevron filings warrant careful validation.
  • Purification of dividends/distributable income at the ratio of 2.1% is mandatory for compliant investment participation.
  • Pending approval from the Shariah supervisory board is required due to defense sector concerns and quality assurance issues detected.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

  • The holding is currently allowed subject to purification of approximately 0.26% of dividends/earnings to cleanse non-permissible income.
  • Due to the conflicting defense-related flags and upstream data inconsistencies, it is recommended to HOLD or AVOID initiating new positions until the Shariah board completes its review.
  • Monitor updates for the Shariah board’s final verdict and ensure purification processes are strictly followed during dividend distribution.
  • Be vigilant on disclosures and possible further clarifications relating to defense sector revenue and non-permissible income sources to avoid investment in impermissible activities.

haram_global_reasoning: UnitedHealth Group’s 2024 Form 10‑K shows total revenues of $400.3B, of which Premiums are $308.8B. Of the Premiums, $286.0B are recorded in the UnitedHealthcare segment (the company’s conventional insurer). We treat these as clearly non‑permissible due to the gharar/maisir/riba inherent in conventional insurance. We do not include UnitedHealthcare services revenue (administrative fees for ASO/self‑funded clients) nor Optum revenues (PBM, care delivery, analytics), which are not clearly haram under the dual‑use rule. We allocate the $286.0B of UnitedHealthcare premiums proportionally across UHC business lines using the 10‑K’s revenue table by business (E&I Domestic, E&I Global, Medicare & Retirement, Community & State). This produces an estimated 71.5% of total company revenue from conventional insurance premiums. Compared to the 5% NPIN threshold, total haram revenue is well above 5% and therefore fails the rule.
haram_limitations: UnitedHealthcare reports total revenues by business line, but does not disclose premium vs. services split for each sub‑line; we therefore allocate the total UHC premium pool to sub‑lines proportionally to each sub‑line’s reported revenue. Medicare & Retirement is not broken further into MA vs. Medigap vs. Part D in revenue terms; composition therefore remains at the business‑line level. Optum Health records some 'premium' revenue from value‑based provider arrangements; we exclude those because they are provider risk contracts (not the sale of insurance to consumers), consistent with industry practice and dual‑use logic.

Executive Summary

Chevron Corporation’s Shariah screening results in a NON_COMPLIANT verdict with a screening status of FAIL.

  • Reported Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) ratio: 0.26%
  • Estimated haram-sector share of revenue: approximately 72.8% (range 71.5%–74.0%)
  • Main haram income drivers: Conventional health insurance premiums from UnitedHealthcare (~71.5% of revenue) and interest/investment income (riba) (~1.3% of revenue)
  • Debt ratio is 8.14%, within acceptable limits
  • Cash and investments ratio is 18.00%, within limits

Due to the significant exposure to conventional insurance revenue and riba-based income, the company fails Shariah compliance criteria, and it is recommended to avoid new investments.

  3. REF_SHARIAH_CONV_INS Shariah screening principle: conventional insurance (gharar/maisir/riba) is non-permissible (industry knowledge, as of 2025-12-26)
  4. REF_SHARIAH_RIBA Shariah screening principle: interest (riba) is non-permissible (industry knowledge, as of 2025-12-26)

Final Shariah Verdict

Verdict: NON_COMPLIANT

Chevron Corporation fails the Shariah compliance screening primarily due to a substantial proportion of revenue derived from conventional health insurance premiums and non-permissible interest income. Despite passing quantitative ratio limits, the nature of the core business segments leads to non-compliance.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • Conventional insurance business models involve gharar (excessive uncertainty), maisir (gambling), and riba (interest), rendering related revenue haram.
  • Interest income from investment and other financial activities constitutes riba and is fully non-permissible.
  • Purification is not recommended given the overwhelming proportion of haram revenue (~72.8%).
  • Company is not considered dual-use or neutral; majority of revenues are core-haram.
  • Debt levels and NPIN percentages meet standard screening thresholds but do not override the dominant haram income streams.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

It is recommended to avoid new investments in Chevron Corporation due to its non-compliance with Shariah screening criteria, specifically the high share of conventional insurance-related revenue and riba income. Current holdings should be reviewed in line with firm policy and Shariah Board guidance.

No purification is advised given the dominant haram revenue composition. Portfolio managers should monitor any changes in business model or disclosure that might affect compliance status and reassess accordingly.

shariah_memo_markdown:
UnitedHealth Group Incorporated (UNH) – Shariah Compliance Report

1. Header Snapshot

  • Ticker: UNH
  • Report Date: 2025-10-28
  • Sector: Medical - Healthcare Plans
  • Type of Security: Common Stock (COM)
  • Screening Status: FAIL
  • Final Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

2. Executive Summary

UnitedHealth Group Incorporated fails the Shariah screening primarily due to its core involvement in conventional health insurance and managed care operations, which are non-permissible. While the non-permissible income (NPIN) ratio stands at a low 1.04% of total revenue, the company’s fundamental business model involves conventional insurance products that generate gharar, maisir, and riba concerns. The estimated haram-sector share of revenue is approximately 1.8%, falling below the 5% NPIN threshold; thus, purification is not mandatory. Key non-permissible income drivers are primarily related to interest income on treasury cash and investments and conventional financing activities.

3. Company Overview

Exchange: N/A

Country: N/A

Reporting Period: 2025-10-28

Company Description:

UnitedHealth Group Incorporated is a leading diversified healthcare company focused on offering a wide range of health care plans and services. Its operations include managed care, health benefit programs, and ancillary health services. The company serves individuals, employers, and public sector clients through its two main platforms, UnitedHealthcare and Optum Health. It plays a significant role in conventional health insurance and managed care markets in the United States.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Managed health insurance plans
  • Medicare and Medicaid services
  • Employer-sponsored insurance products
  • Optum health services and pharmacy care
  • Conventional health insurance underwriting

4. Quantitative Shariah Screening

Financial Ratio Value Shariah Threshold Compliant?
Debt Ratio 25.21% <= 33% Yes
Cash & Investments Ratio 26.71% <= 33% Yes
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio 1.04% <= 5% Yes

5. Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

Estimated haram revenue stands at approximately 1.8% of total revenue, within a range of 1.2% to 2.4%. The main contributors to non-permissible income include non-operating interest income from treasury cash and investments and conventional financing activities related to loans and fees. The company’s conventional health insurance operations also render the core business non-compliant despite the relatively low NPIN ratio.

Haram Revenue Composition

Item / Line Point % of Total Revenue Range (Lower – Upper) Why Non-Permissible Reference IDs
Non-operating interest income (treasury cash and investments) ~1.1% 0.6% – 1.5% Riba from interest-bearing bank deposits and marketable debt securities N/A
Conventional financing (IBM Financing) ~0.7% 0.57% – 0.91% Conventional interest income and fees from client and commercial loans and leases N/A

Note: Detailed item-level composition for haram income was not provided for UnitedHealth Group specifically.

6. Final Shariah Verdict

Overall Verdict: NON_COMPLIANT
Despite the low level of non-permissible income by percentage of total revenue, UnitedHealth Group’s core operations are in conventional health insurance and managed care, which are prohibited sectors under Shariah due to elements of uncertainty (gharar), gambling (maisir), and interest (riba). Therefore, the company fails the Shariah screening.

7. Key Shariah Considerations

  • Core business involves conventional health insurance plans including Medicare Advantage, commercial fully insured plans, ACA offerings, and employer insurance products.
  • Conventional insurance operations inherently involve gharar, maisir, and riba, rendering the business model non-permissible.
  • Non-operating interest income derived from treasury cash and investments contributes to non-permissible income.
  • Conventional financing activities generate additional interest and fee income that is non-permissible.
  • Reported NPIN ratio of 1.04% is below the 5% threshold, but the prohibited sector classification dominates the final compliance decision.
  • No purification is required based on the reported NPIN and company business model assessment.

8. Guidance for Portfolio Managers

UnitedHealth Group is classified as a non-compliant security under Shariah due to its foundational business in conventional health insurance and related non-permissible practices. Although the estimated non-permissible income share is approximately 1.8%, purification of dividends or earnings at this level is noted but may not align with accepted Shariah standards given the core prohibited sector nature. Portfolio managers should carefully consider exclusion or avoidance of this holding in fully Shariah-compliant portfolios. Where held, appropriate client disclosures and purification mechanisms should be applied.

shariah_memo_markdown:
International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) - Shariah Compliance Report

1. Header Snapshot

  • Ticker: IBM
  • Company Name: International Business Machines Corporation
  • Report Date: 2025-10-22
  • Sector: Information Technology Services
  • Type of Security: Common Stock (COM)
  • Screening Status: PASS_WITH_PURIFICATION
  • Final Classification: COMPLIANT_WITH_PURIFICATION

2. Executive Summary

International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) has passed the Shariah equity screening with a status of PASS_WITH_PURIFICATION. The company’s reported Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) ratio stands at 3.23% of revenue, below the widely accepted 5% threshold. A purification of 3.23% of distributable income is recommended to cleanse the earnings from non-permissible sources. The haram sector revenue is estimated at approximately 1.33%, with a range between 1.2% and 1.5%. The primary source of non-permissible income is conventional interest (riba) earned on cash, cash equivalents, and marketable investments. No other significant haram business segments or revenue lines are identified.

3. Company Overview

International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) is a global leader in information technology services and solutions. The company provides a broad portfolio of offerings including cloud computing, artificial intelligence, quantum computing, and IT infrastructure services. IBM serves a diverse client base across multiple industries, delivering enterprise technology and consulting solutions. The company’s technology platforms support digital transformation and data-driven decision-making for businesses worldwide.

  • General-purpose IT and cloud infrastructure services
  • AI software and enterprise solutions including WatsonX
  • Quantum computing and advanced technology services
  • Consulting and IT service management
  • Technology partnerships with financial institutions and government entities

4. Quantitative Shariah Screening

Parameter Value (%) Threshold
Debt Ratio 20.12 ≤ 33%
Cash and Investments Ratio 5.61 ≤ 33%
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio 3.23 ≤ 5%

The company meets all canonical financial ratio thresholds consistent with standard Islamic equity screening parameters and exhibits a moderate level of interest income exposure.

5. Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

The main driver of non-permissible income is interest income (riba) from cash, cash equivalents, and investment-grade fixed-income securities, accounting for approximately 1.33% of total revenue.

Haram Revenue Composition

Item / Line Point % of total revenue Range (lower–upper) Why non-permissible Reference IDs
Interest income from cash, cash equivalents, and investment-grade fixed-income securities 1.33% 1.2% – 1.5% Conventional interest (riba) received on deposits and fixed-income securities is non-permissible under widely used Shariah equity standards MU_FY2025_PR, MU_2024_10K

Haram Sector Summary: The haram segment solely consists of conventional interest income which is clearly identified and quantified. No other haram sectors including alcohol, gambling, pork, adult entertainment, or dedicated weapons platforms were identified in the company's business model or revenue streams.

References

  1. MU_FY2025_PR: Micron Technology, Inc. – FY2025 Q4 and Full Year results press release (includes Consolidated Statements of Operations) (filing, as of 2025-09-23) — FY2025 Interest income of $496m and total revenue of $37,378m used to compute the ~1.33% NPIN share. — Link
  2. MU_2024_10K: Micron Technology, Inc. – Form 10-K for fiscal year ended Aug 29, 2024 (filing, as of 2024-10-04) — Description of cash and investments as bank deposits, money market funds, and liquid investment-grade fixed-income; discussion that interest income reflects returns on cash and investments. — Link

6. Final Shariah Verdict

Classification: COMPLIANT_WITH_PURIFICATION

IBM satisfies all key Shariah quantitative and qualitative criteria, passing the screening with purification required on the identified non-permissible income portion only. The recommended purification is approximately 1.33% of total revenue, corresponding to the interest income component. This approach aligns with the common Shariah equity standards allowing a limited NPIN tolerance level (up to 5%) with purification measures.

7. Key Shariah Considerations

  • The only identified haram income is conventional interest on liquid assets, constituting ~1.33% of revenue.
  • The company operates in the information technology services sector, providing general-purpose technological solutions with no inherent non-permissible business lines.
  • IBM’s involvement with financial institution clients is limited to technology provision and does not generate direct interest income or haram revenue streams.
  • Debt and cash ratios remain within accepted Shariah screening limits.
  • The purification requirement is limited to the measured non-permissible interest income portion and is manageable through dividend purification.
  • Due to some exposure to clients in conventional financial and insurance industries and dual-use technology caution, monitoring is advisable but no direct Shariah breach is evident in IBM’s own revenue.

8. Guidance for Portfolio Managers

IBM is deemed an allowed holding under Shariah-compliant investment guidelines with a purification ratio of approximately 1.33% of dividends or distributable income. Portfolio managers should:

  • Implement purification procedures on distributable earnings corresponding to the NPIN ratio of 3.23% and the haram revenue point estimate of 1.33%.
  • Continue monitoring company disclosures for any material changes in non-permissible income sources, particularly conventional interest income from investments.
  • Note that IBM’s business model is primarily within permissible sectors despite providing technology services to some conventional finance sector clients.
  • Maintain awareness of dual-use technology risks and consult Shariah advisors if new product lines or business partnerships emerge that may impact permissibility.
  • Consider re-screening if company financials indicate significant deviation in NPIN, debt, or cash ratios exceeding thresholds.

haram_global_reasoning: Denominator: 2024 consolidated sales and revenues of $64.809bn. Financial Products revenues are split between Cat Financial and Insurance Services. Cat Financial reported $3.489bn revenues in 2024 (largely interest/finance revenue plus operating lease and other). Quarter disclosures show Financial Products segment revenue of $1.024bn in Q4 2024, while Cat Financial alone reported $0.883bn in Q4 2024; the $0.141bn difference approximates Insurance Services revenue that quarter. Annualizing that Q4 gap gives ≈$0.564bn Insurance Services revenue in 2024. Cat Financial’s 2023 10-K (subsidiary) breaks out revenue into retail finance (interest), wholesale finance (interest), operating lease (rental) and other; we step forward to 2024 by scaling retail and wholesale (interest) upward to match the known 2024 total and the company’s stated drivers (higher average financing rates and earning assets), while keeping operating lease roughly stable. We then: (a) include retail and wholesale finance revenues (riba-based), (b) include an estimated haram portion of Cat Financial’s ‘other’ (primarily interest/finance charges on cash/securities and certain fees) using a conservative 70% factor, and (c) include Insurance Services revenue (conventional insurance). Operating lease rentals are not counted as haram. The resulting point estimate is ~4.74% of consolidated revenue, with a range of ~4.13%–5.30% to reflect estimation and mix uncertainty. Against a 5% NPIN rule, the point estimate is below 5% but close; purification is advised and the upper bound can exceed 5% depending on mix.
haram_limitations: Insurance Services revenue is not disclosed as a standalone full-year figure in the public summaries we cite; we infer ≈$0.564bn by annualizing the Q4 2024 gap between Financial Products segment revenues and Cat Financial revenues. Cat Financial 2024 line-item split (retail vs. wholesale vs. operating lease vs. other) is estimated from the subsidiary’s 2023 10-K profile and the 2024 growth drivers; exact 2024 line-item amounts were not located in a single table. The ‘other’ finance revenue haram share uses a 70% industry-knowledge factor; actual mix may vary. If Caterpillar later publishes a detailed 2024/2025 breakdown, these estimates should be refreshed.

shariah_memo_markdown:
Shariah Compliance Report: Micron Technology, Inc. (MU)

1. Header Snapshot

  • Ticker: MU
  • Company Name: Micron Technology, Inc.
  • Report Date: 2025-09-23
  • Sector: Semiconductors
  • Type of Security: Common Stock (COM)
  • Screening Status: FAIL
  • Final Classification: NON_COMPLIANT
  • Debt Ratio: 5.3%
  • Cash & Investments Ratio: 4.14%
  • Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio: 1.33%
  • Estimated Haram Revenue (Point Estimate): ≈ 4.7% (Range: 4.1%–5.3%)
  • Purification Ratio Applied: 1.33% of distributable income

2. Executive Summary

Micron Technology, Inc. is classified as Non-Compliant based on Shariah screening criteria, primarily due to its involvement in Financial Products generating interest and conventional insurance income. The estimated non-permissible revenue is approximately 4.7% of total revenue, with a range from 4.1% to 5.3%, placing it close to the 5% threshold for non-permissible income (NPIN). Despite the NPIN reported at 1.33%, and a purification applied at the same level, the total haram exposure on revenue exceeds the threshold in its upper estimate and is sufficiently material to warrant a fail status.

There are no major operational Shariah issues within Micron’s core semiconductor business, which is considered dual-use or neutral infrastructure. The haram exposure arises exclusively from a minor revenue segment related to Financial Products and Insurance Services, including interest-bearing finance and conventional insurance.

3. Company Overview

Exchange: N/A

Country: N/A

Reporting Period: 2025-09-23

Company Description: Micron Technology, Inc. is a leading global semiconductor company specializing in memory and storage solutions. The company designs and manufactures a variety of advanced semiconductor devices that serve industries such as computing, networking, and consumer electronics. Their core business supports infrastructure technologies that enable digital transformation across multiple sectors.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Semiconductor memory and storage products
  • Advanced wafer fabrication and packaging
  • Technology solutions for computing and mobile markets
  • Support services for global supply chains
  • Small Financial Products and Insurance Services segment

4. Quantitative Shariah Screening

  • Debt Ratio: 5.3% (<33% threshold) — Compliant
  • Cash & Investments Ratio: 4.14% (<33% threshold) — Compliant
  • Non-Permissible Income Ratio (NPIN): 1.33% (≤5% rule) — Within limit
  • Purification Ratio: 1.33% of distributable income applied
  • Screening Status: FAIL
  • QA Status: ISSUES (3) - includes data validity flags and borderline haram percentages

5. Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

The primary source of non-permissible income stems from Micron’s Financial Products segment, comprising interest-based retail and wholesale financing activities and conventional insurance services. The operating lease components within this segment are excluded from haram calculation and considered permissible rental income.
