6. Final Shariah Verdict

Overall Verdict: NON_COMPLIANT

Details: Although the reported NPIN ratio of 1.33% is below the 5% threshold, the estimated haram revenue exposure of approximately 4.7% (point estimate) is near the limit and could exceed it on the upper bound (up to 5.3%). This combined with minor QA issues and the nature of financial product income results in a FAIL screening status. Purification at the reported NPIN ratio is applied, but not sufficient to resolve compliance fully given the close proximity to the threshold and the materiality of haram sources.

7. Key Shariah Considerations

  • Primary non-compliant revenue arises from interest-based retail and wholesale finance provided by Cat Financial and the associated conventional insurance segment.
  • Operating lease rentals within the Financial Products segment are excluded from non-permissible calculations and treated as halal rental income.
  • Micron’s core semiconductor manufacturing and product offerings are dual-use/neutral infrastructure with no direct Shariah compliance issues.
  • Reported NPIN is well-calculated but estimates on certain revenue components (e.g., Insurance Services revenue and ‘other’ finance income) involve assumptions and conservative factors.
  • Though close to the 5% NPIN threshold, the upper bound of the haram revenue range surpasses this limit, supporting the fail classification.
  • Purification of dividends/earnings at ~4.7% is recommended due to the non-negligible haram exposure.

8. Guidance for Portfolio Managers

Holdings in Micron Technology, Inc. should be monitored carefully given the borderline NPIN and fail screening status. The position is allowed with the application of purification at approximately 4.7% of dividends or distributable earnings, consistent with the company’s estimated non-permissible income exposure.

Portfolio managers should be aware that the NPIN figure reported at 1.33% reflects purification already applied, but the full haram revenue estimate is higher and may vary due to assumptions in segment revenue splits. Close attention to updates in segment disclosures, especially regarding Financial Products and Insurance Services, is advised to review purification ratios and compliance status.

No board review or escalation is presently required. However, the exposure to conventional banking-related financial segments remains a key red flag. Replacement strategy should consider alternatives with clear pass status if client mandates are strict on NPIN limits.

haram_global_reasoning: American Express is a card issuer and bank; its consolidated revenue includes a substantial net interest income component driven primarily by revolving Card Member loans. Under Shariah, interest (riba) income is clearly non-permissible. We therefore classify net interest income as haram. We treat merchant discount revenue, net card fees, and most service fees as fees for payment network/services (dual-use) and not inherently haram. Quantitatively, Q1–Q2 2025 filings show net interest income of ~$8.36bn against Total revenues net of interest expense of ~$34.82bn (≈24%). Quarterly run-rate and Q3 disclosures indicate a similar mix, so we set a 22–27% range with a 24.5% point estimate. Note: some methodologies use gross interest income rather than net; that would push the haram share higher. Regardless, total haram revenue materially exceeds the 5% NPIN threshold.
haram_limitations: Percentages are based on the company’s reported Total revenues net of interest expense. We use net interest income (not gross) to avoid double-counting funding costs; some standards purify on gross interest income, which would raise the haram share by several percentage points. Filings do not fully split net interest income between card loans and other interest-bearing assets; allocation within this segment is estimated using disclosed components and management adjustments. Estimates reflect 2025 year-to-date mix and may vary intra-year.

shariah_memo_markdown:
Shariah Compliance Report Snapshot

Company: Caterpillar Inc. (Ticker: CAT)

Sector: Agricultural - Machinery

Security Type: Common Stock (COM)

Report Date: 2025-10-29

Screening Status: FAIL

Final Shariah Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

Executive Summary

Caterpillar Inc. has been evaluated for Shariah compliance based on its financial and business activities as of the reporting date October 29, 2025. The company fails the Shariah screening primarily due to significant revenue derived from interest-based income and penalty-related fees associated with conventional lending practices. The estimated share of non-permissible (haram) revenue is approximately 26.3%, well above the 5% threshold for permissible non-permissible income (NPIN) in Shariah screening. Despite compliance on quantitative thresholds such as debt ratios and NPIN percentage, the material presence of riba-based income and related fees renders the overall business non-compliant.

Company Overview

Exchange: N/A

Country: N/A

Reporting Period: 2025

Company Description: Caterpillar Inc. is a global leader in the manufacturing and distribution of agricultural machinery and related industrial equipment. The company provides machinery, engines, and financial products and services to a broad spectrum of industries worldwide. Caterpillar’s operations encompass the design, manufacture, and servicing of a wide range of durable equipment essential for agricultural and industrial applications.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Manufacturing and sales of agricultural machinery
  • Industrial and construction equipment production
  • Financial products and services related to equipment financing
  • Leasing and credit activities
  • Support and maintenance services

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Metric Value (%) Threshold / Criteria Status
Debt Ratio 13.11% ≤ 33% PASS
Cash & Investments Ratio 8.69% ≤ 33% PASS
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) 0.74% ≤ 5% PASS

Note: Despite passing quantitative NPIN and leverage metrics, the company fails the overall screening due to significant involvement in conventional interest-based income and penalty fee activities making the total haram revenue approximately 26.3% of total revenue.

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

The principal sources of non-permissible income identified are interest-based income from financial products and penalty-related fees tied to conventional lending.

Haram Revenue Composition

Item / Line Point % of Total Revenue Range (Lower–Upper %) Why Non-Permissible Reference IDs
Net interest from Card Member loans (revolving credit/Pay Over Time) 23.5% 21.0% – 26.0% Riba from charging interest on revolving card balances and installment features (conventional lending). AXP_10Q_Q1_2025, AXP_10Q_Q2_2025, AXP_IR_Q2_2025_PR
Net interest from other interest-bearing assets (deposits with banks, investment securities, liquidity portfolio) 1.0% 0.5% – 1.5% Riba earned on non-loan interest-bearing assets (e.g., bank deposits, fixed-income securities). AXP_10Q_Q1_2025, AXP_10Q_Q2_2025
Delinquency (late payment) fees 1.35% 1.2% – 1.6% Late payment penalties on conventional credit are non-permissible. AXP_10Q_Q1_2025, AXP_10Q_Q2_2025, Industry_Knowledge
Cash-advance related fees 0.45% 0.2% – 0.7% Fees charged for advancing cash on conventional credit products are tied to riba-based lending and treated as non-permissible. AXP_10Q_Q2_2025, Industry_Knowledge

Summary of Haram Revenue

Estimated total haram revenue: Approximately 26.3% (range: 23.4% – 29.3%).

Main haram drivers: Interest-based income (~24.5%), penalty and cash-advance fees (~1.8%).

References

  1. AXP_10Q_Q1_2025: American Express Company Form 10-Q (Quarter ended March 31, 2025) – revenue breakdown, net interest income, and service fees components (filing, as_of 2025-03-31) — supports identification and sizing of interest income/expense and classification of revenues — Link
  2. AXP_10Q_Q2_2025: American Express Company Form 10-Q (Quarter ended June 30, 2025) – consolidation of revenue lines; net interest income; six-month revenue mix (filing, as_of 2025-06-30) — supports six-month net interest income figures and interest income components — Link
  3. AXP_IR_Q2_2025_PR: American Express Q2 2025 earnings release (third party estimate, as_of 2025-07-18) — supports management commentary on revenue growth driven by net interest income — Link
  4. Industry_Knowledge: Industry practice and Shariah screening norms for conventional credit products (industry knowledge, as_of 2025-12-26) — supports treatment of late payment penalties and cash-advance fees as non-permissible and magnitude estimation — N/A

Final Shariah Verdict

Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

The company is deemed non-compliant due to a substantial proportion of revenue generated from impermissible sources, primarily interest-based income and related penalty fees integrated into its financial products. Given the total non-permissible income far exceeds the 5% threshold, the company fails the overall Shariah compliance screening despite passing quantitative debt and NPIN ratio checks.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • The core issue remains the substantial interest (riba) income from revolving credit and other interest-bearing financial assets, which are strictly non-permissible under Islamic finance principles.
  • Penalty fees related to late payments and cash advances are also considered haram as they stem from conventional credit practices involving riba.
  • While the company’s primary agricultural machinery business may be operational or dual-use, the large impact of financial products related to conventional lending dictates overall non-compliance.
  • Quantitative NPIN of 0.74% is reported, but material haram revenue is embedded in business activities classified under non-permissible sectors.
  • The company does not require purification currently due to NPIN levels; however, investment avoidance is advised due to the high haram revenue content.
  • Shariah references emphasize the 5% NPIN threshold and the prohibition against assisting in prohibited activities (ta’awun ‘ala al-ithm), reinforcing the non-compliance status.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

  • Avoid new investments in Caterpillar Inc. due to its failure in Shariah compliance screening.
  • Consider existing exposure carefully, given the substantial non-permissible income portion.
  • No purification is currently recommended; however, ongoing monitoring for changes in financial product mix and revenue composition is necessary.
  • Review alternative investment opportunities that comply fully with Shariah principles to maintain portfolio integrity.
  • Note that this report indicates QA issues unrelated to Shariah compliance but relevant for overall data integrity; exercise caution in data interpretation.

shariah_memo_markdown:
Shariah Compliance Report Snapshot: American Express Company (AXP)

  • Ticker: AXP
  • Company Name: American Express Company
  • Report Date: 2025-10-17
  • Sector: Financial - Credit Services
  • Screening Status: FAIL
  • Final Shariah Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

Executive Summary

The Shariah screening of American Express Company resulted in a FAIL status with a final classification of NON_COMPLIANT. The key quantitative drivers are a reported non-permissible income (NPIN) ratio of 32.07% and an estimated haram-sector share of revenue at approximately 0.7% (range 0.4%–0.9%). The main source of haram income is identified as non-operating finance income comprising interest, investment and derivative gains. The company operates a conventional financial services business centered on credit card issuance and conventional consumer finance, which are inherently non-permissible under Shariah law. Purification of approximately 0.65% of distributable income is likely recommended.

Company Overview

Exchange: N/A

Country: N/A

Reporting Period: N/A

Company Description: American Express Company is a leading global financial services corporation specializing in payment card products and services. The company issues consumer and business credit cards and operates a large merchant acceptance network. American Express is known for its premium card offerings and extensive customer engagement initiatives.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Consumer credit card issuance
  • Business credit card solutions
  • Merchant payment acceptance network
  • Reward and loyalty program management
  • Financial services and payment processing

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Metric Value (%) Shariah Threshold
Debt to Asset Ratio 18.82 <= 33%
Cash and Investments Ratio 92.41 <= 33% (Note: Exceeds threshold)
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio 32.07 <= 5% (Note: Exceeds threshold)

Note: The elevated cash and investments ratio along with a high NPIN percentage indicate significant non-permissible financial activities, signaling caution.

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

Estimated Haram Share of Revenue: ≈ 0.7% (range 0.4%–0.9%)

Main Haram Segment: Non-operating finance income (interest, investment and derivative gains)

Item / Line Point % of Total Revenue Range (Lower–Upper %) Why Non-Permissible Reference IDs
Interest income on cash, cash equivalents and short‑term investments 0.45% 0.3%–0.6% Conventional interest (riba) earned on deposits and marketable securities is non‑permissible and requires purification. context_npin_feed, analyst_industry_knowledge
Realized/unrealized investment gains and dividend income 0.10% 0%–0.2% Gains/dividends from conventional fixed‑income or mixed investment portfolios (and from impermissible equities, if any) are treated as non‑permissible income. context_npin_feed, analyst_industry_knowledge
Net gains on FX and derivative hedging instruments 0.10% 0%–0.2% Income from conventional derivatives used for hedging (forwards, options, swaps) is generally treated as non‑permissible and requires purification. context_npin_feed, analyst_industry_knowledge

References

  1. [context_npin_feed] Provided NPIN_Ratio in context block (~0.65% of revenue) (industry_knowledge, as_of 2025-10-30) — Overall NPIN baseline for Merck & Co., used to anchor point estimate and bounds.
  2. [analyst_industry_knowledge] Industry knowledge: Big Pharma financial statement structure (interest and other income typically <1% of revenue) (industry_knowledge, as_of 2025-12-26) — Expected composition across interest income, investment gains/dividends, and derivative/FX gains; interpretation under the 5% rule.

Final Shariah Verdict

Status: FAIL

Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

The company’s core business as a conventional consumer finance and credit card issuer inherently violates Shariah principles due to the reliance on interest-based financial services. Despite the estimated haram revenue share being below the 5% threshold, the structural nature of its business results in a non-compliant verdict.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • Core business model involves conventional lending and credit card issuance which is non-permissible.
  • High NPIN ratio of 32.07% indicates substantial presence of non-permissible income components.
  • Haram income primarily stems from interest, conventional investment gains/dividends, and derivative hedging instruments.
  • Cash and investments ratio significantly exceeds the Shariah threshold, indicating potential risk of further riba income.
  • The company is flagged multiple times for conventional banking activities and interest income cores.
  • Purification is advised around 0.65% of distributable income to compensate for non-permissible earnings identified.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

American Express Company is currently classified as non-compliant with major Shariah concerns related to its interest-based conventional financial services and credit card business. The company may be held conditionally with purification recommended on roughly 0.65% of distributable dividend or earnings. Portfolio managers should carefully consider the elevated NPIN, cash holdings, and structural violations when deciding on inclusion. A formal Shariah board review is advised to reconcile conflicting NPIN and interest figures flagged during upstream screening. Until such review, a cautious hold or avoid stance is prudent to maintain Shariah integrity of portfolios.

shariah_memo_markdown:
Shariah Compliance Report: Merck & Co., Inc. (MRK)

1. Header Snapshot

  • Ticker: MRK
  • Company Name: Merck & Co., Inc.
  • Report Date: 2025-10-30
  • Sector: Drug Manufacturers - General
  • Type of Security: Common Stock (COM)
  • Overall Screening Status: FAIL
  • Final Shariah Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

2. Executive Summary

Merck & Co., Inc. has been assessed for Shariah compliance for the fiscal period ending October 30, 2025. The company’s total non-permissible income (NPIN) ratio is 0.65% of revenue, with a haram revenue estimate approximately 1.3% (range: 1.1% to 1.4%). The primary source of non-permissible income is conventional interest on cash and cash equivalents. Despite the NPIN being below the 5% purification threshold, the overall screening status is a fail, leading to a final classification of non-compliant. Purification of the dividends/earnings is recommended to account for the incidental riba income.

3. Company Overview

Merck & Co., Inc. is a leading global pharmaceutical company specializing in the research, development, manufacture, and marketing of innovative medicines, vaccines, and animal health products. The company operates extensively in the healthcare industry, focusing on therapeutic solutions for a wide range of conditions. Merck is recognized for its dedication to advancing medical science and improving health outcomes worldwide.

  • Pharmaceutical research and development
  • Human health medicines and vaccines
  • Animal health products
  • Global distribution and sales of pharmaceutical products

4. Quantitative Shariah Screening

Financial Ratio Value (%) Shariah Threshold Status
Debt Ratio 15.38 <= 33.00 Pass
Cash & Investments Ratio 5.69 <= 33.00 Pass
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio 0.65 <= 5.00 Pass

Despite all key ratios passing set thresholds, the company fails overall screening due to the presence of non-permissible income requiring purification.

5. Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

Haram Revenue Composition:

Item / Line Point % of Total Revenue Range (Lower–Upper %) Why Non-Permissible Reference IDs
Interest from money market funds (cash-equivalent funds) 0.75% 0.6% – 0.9% Income arises from conventional interest-bearing instruments held within money market funds; riba income is non-permissible and requires purification. ref_lrcx_2025_10k_interest, ref_lrcx_2025_10k_casheq_mix
Interest from bank time deposits and short-term deposits 0.45% 0.35% – 0.6% Conventional time deposits pay interest; such riba-based returns are non-permissible and must be purified. ref_lrcx_2025_10k_interest, ref_lrcx_2025_10k_casheq_mix
Other interest (interest-bearing bank balances, tax interest, misc.) 0.05% 0% – 0.1% Residual conventional interest not captured above (e.g., on interest-bearing operating cash or incidental items). Treated as riba and purified. ref_lrcx_2025_10k_interest, ref_lrcx_2025_q3_10q_note5

Summary of Haram Segment

The non-permissible income is exclusively derived from conventional interest earned on cash and cash equivalent holdings such as money market funds, bank time deposits, and other interest-bearing bank balances. This constitutes approximately 1.25% of total revenue, well below the 5% NPIN threshold allowing the company to be held with required purification measures.

References

  1. ref_lrcx_2025_10k_interest: Lam Research Corporation Form 10-K (FY ended June 29, 2025) – Note 6: Other income (expense), net; Consolidated Statements of Operations — Audited FY25 interest income of $231.331m and total revenue of $18,435.591m used to compute the 1.25% NPIN ratio. — URL
  2. ref_lrcx_2025_10k_casheq_mix: Lam Research Corporation Form 10-K (FY ended June 29, 2025) – Financial instruments within Cash and cash equivalents — Composition of cash and cash equivalents (money market funds ~$3.15bn; cash ~$1.66bn; time deposits ~$1.58bn) informing the interest-income split. — URL
  3. ref_lrcx_2025_q3_10q_note5: Lam Research Corporation Form 10-Q (Quarter ended March 30, 2025) – Note 5: Other income (expense), net — Quarterly and nine‑month interest income detail; disclosure that interest income varies with cash balances/rates; confirmation of cash equivalents including money market funds and time deposits. — URL

6. Final Shariah Verdict

Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

Reasoning: Although the NPIN ratio (0.65%) is below the 5% threshold, the combined estimated non-permissible revenue contribution of approximately 1.25% from conventional interest income mandates purification. The company fails the overall Shariah compliance screening due to the presence of incidental riba-based income from cash management activities.

Screening Status: FAIL

7. Key Shariah Considerations

  • Non-permissible income arises exclusively from incidental conventional interest on cash and cash equivalents.
  • The company does not engage in inherently haram business activities or sectors.
  • The level of non-permissible income requires purification but remains below maximum threshold limits.
  • No additional material Shariah concerns or operational flags were identified.
  • The pharmaceutical operations remain fully permissible and neutral from a Shariah perspective.
  • Shariah references applicable include the 5% NPIN threshold and avoidance of assisting in sin (ta’awun ‘ala al-ithm).

8. Guidance for Portfolio Managers

The holding of Merck & Co., Inc. is permitted with the condition of purification of dividends/earnings to account for the estimated 1.25% non-permissible income related to conventional interest. Portfolio managers should ensure that such purification is rigorously applied in accordance with Islamic finance principles. There is no indication of any direct involvement in haram sectors aside from incidental interest income, and the overall operational activities are consistent with Shariah compliance requirements.

It is recommended to periodically review the cash management strategies impacting interest income to monitor any material changes to NPIN levels and reassess purification needs accordingly.

shariah_memo_markdown:
Shariah Compliance Report: Lam Research Corporation (LRCX)

Report Date: 2025-10-22

Executive Summary

Lam Research Corporation ("Lam Research"), a company operating in the semiconductors sector, has been evaluated for Shariah compliance. Despite meeting key quantitative financial ratios (debt, cash & investments, non-permissible income), the company fails the overall Shariah screening due to earnings from non-permissible interest income. The estimated non-compliant revenue portion is approximately 2.5% (range: 1.8%–3.0%) derived primarily from non-operating interest and finance income.

This results in a final Shariah verdict of NON_COMPLIANT, requiring purification of dividends at about 2.51%. The company’s core semiconductor equipment business, considered neutral or permissible under dual-use assessment, is free from haram involvement.

Company Overview

Ticker: LRCX

Sector: Semiconductors

Exchange: N/A

Country: N/A

Reporting Period: N/A

Description:

Lam Research Corporation is a provider of innovative semiconductor manufacturing equipment and services. The company designs and manufactures systems that automate the fabrication of integrated circuits for semiconductor chips. Their technology supports chipmakers in improving yields, performance, and production efficiency while enabling advances in electronics technology.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Semiconductor wafer fabrication equipment
  • Advanced process control and automation solutions
  • Material engineering and surface preparation tools
  • Maintenance and service contracts

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Financial Parameter Value Threshold Status
Debt Ratio 2.24% <= 33% Pass
Cash & Investment Ratio 3.02% <= 33% Pass
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio 1.25% <= 5% Pass

Note: Despite passing key numeric thresholds, final screening status is FAIL due to qualitative analysis of interest income sources and Shariah board interpretation.

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

Haram Revenue Composition:

Item / Line % of Total Revenue (Point Estimate) Range (%) Why Non-Permissible Reference IDs
Interest on cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments 2.25% 1.6% – 2.7% Riba from placement of surplus cash in conventional interest-bearing deposits, money market instruments and marketable securities. TMO_IR_Q3_2025, BusinessQuant_InterestIncome_2025Q2, TMO_Q2_2025_BW
Customer financing and lease interest (Thermo Fisher Financial Solutions) 0.15% 0.05% – 0.3% Conventional finance charges embedded in customer equipment leases/extended terms and subscription financing. TMO_Financial_Solutions_Fisher, TMO_Financing_Leasing_Site, TMO_SEC_10K_2023
Other interest and investment income (e.g., notes receivable, restricted cash, miscellaneous) 0.11% 0.05% – 0.2% Residual riba from interest-bearing financial assets not separately disclosed; included within the consolidated interest income line. TMO_IR_Q3_2025, TMO_SEC_10K_2023

Summary: Total haram income is estimated at approximately 2.51% of total revenue with a confidence level of 1.0. The primary source of haram income is interest and finance income that is non-operating in nature, mainly generated by conventional interest-bearing instruments and customer lease financing.

References

  1. [TMO_IR_Q3_2025] Thermo Fisher IR press release: Q3 2025 results (filing, 2025-10-22) — Magnitude of quarterly interest income and revenue used to benchmark haram ratio — View source
  2. [TMO_SEC_10K_2023] Thermo Fisher 2023 Form 10-K (filing, 2023-12-31) — Lessor activities disclosed as not material; framing of interest/other income items — View source
  3. [BusinessQuant_InterestIncome_2025Q2] BusinessQuant – Thermo Fisher Interest & Investment Income time series (third_party_estimate, 2025-06-28) — Approximate annual scale of interest/investment income (~$1.1bn FY2024; ~$297m in Q2 2025) — View source
  4. [TMO_Financial_Solutions_Fisher] Fisher Scientific – Thermo Fisher Financial Solutions page (filing, 2025-12-26) — Existence and nature of customer equipment financing/leases — View source
  5. [TMO_Financing_Leasing_Site] Thermo Fisher – Financing & Leasing solutions page (filing, 2025-12-26) — Details of lease/subscription financing offerings (FMV leases, one-dollar buyout, deferrals) — View source
  6. [TMO_Q2_2025_BW] Business Wire – Thermo Fisher Reports Q2 2025 (filing, 2025-07-22) — Large cash and short-term investments base supporting sizable interest income — View source

Final Shariah Verdict

Overall Screening Status: FAIL

Final Classification: NON_COMPLIANT

Estimated Haram Revenue Portion: ≈ 2.51% (range: 1.8% – 3.0%)

Purification Required: No mandatory purification percentage prescribed, though portfolio-level purification of dividends/earnings recommended at approximately 2.51% due to non-operating interest income.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • Non-permissible income mainly stems from riba (interest) earned on cash, cash equivalents, short-term investments, and customer financing/leases.
  • The company’s core semiconductor equipment business is permissible and considered dual-use technology, thus not haram.
  • Total non-compliant income is under 5% NPIN threshold, allowing continued holding with appropriate purification.
  • Uncertainty exists due to incomplete breakdown of interest income sources and minor customer financing revenue.
  • No major concerns related to assisting in sin or transgression were identified.
  • Debt and cash ratios fall well within acceptable Shariah limits.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

Lam Research Corporation is classified as a non-compliant stock due to its non-permissible earnings from interest income. However, the total non-compliant revenue portion is below the 5% threshold, and the company does not engage in haram operational business lines.

Portfolio managers may continue to hold or initiate positions with the following considerations:

  • Apply a purification ratio approximating 2.51% on dividends or earnings derived from Lam Research holdings.
  • Monitor quarterly disclosures for any significant changes in non-operating income streams or financing activities that could affect Shariah status.
  • Ensure transparency in reporting and readiness to reassess if material lease or financing revenue grows.
  • Recognize that the investment aligns with allowable dual-use technology sectors and does not directly facilitate haram activities.

Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. (TMO) – Shariah Compliance Report

Executive Summary

Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. has been screened for Shariah compliance with a final verdict of COMPLIANT_WITH_PURIFICATION. The screening status is PASS_WITH_PURIFICATION, reflecting a non-permissible income ratio (NPIN) of 2.51% of total revenue. The estimated haram revenue portion is approximately 0.82% (range 0.6%–1.0%). This non-permissible income primarily derives from non-operating interest and investment income, which necessitates purification. The company’s financial ratios conform within acceptable Shariah thresholds, confirming suitability for Islamic investment portfolios with purification applied.

Company Overview

Exchange: N/A

Country: N/A

Reporting Period: 2025-10-22

Sector: Medical - Diagnostics & Research

Description: Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. is a leading global life sciences company specializing in diagnostics, research instruments, and related laboratory services and consumables. It focuses on enabling science through a wide range of products and services used in medical research, clinical applications, and pharmaceutical development.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Life sciences research instruments and consumables
  • Clinical diagnostics and laboratory services
  • Biopharma manufacturing solutions
  • Analytical instruments and software

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Metric Value Shariah Threshold Verdict
Debt Ratio (%) 14.94 <= 33% Pass
Cash and Investments Ratio (%) 2.79 <= 33% Pass
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio (%) 2.51 <= 5% Pass with Purification

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

Haram Revenue Composition:

Item / Line Point % of Total Revenue Range (Lower–Upper) % Why Non-Permissible Reference IDs
Interest on cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments (bank deposits, money market, commercial paper) 0.65% 0.45–0.85% Riba-based return from cash and short-term interest-bearing instruments; counted as non-permissible income. SEC_10Q_2025Q3_IS, SEC_10Q_2025Q3_FV, PR_3Q25
Interest on long-term interest-bearing securities (primarily debt-type holdings classified outside cash equivalents) 0.15% 0.05–0.25% Riba-based coupon/interest from long-duration securities held on balance sheet; smaller contributor given modest long-term investment balances in 2025. SEC_10Q_2025Q3_IS, SEC_10Q_2025Q3_FV
Miscellaneous interest-type items (e.g., interest on tax refunds, late-payment interest) 0.02% 0–0.05% Minor riba-linked items occasionally included within interest income; immaterial but included for completeness. industry_alloc

Key Drivers: The sole haram segment identified is the non-operating interest and investment income amounting to approximately 0.82% of total revenue. There are no haram product lines such as alcohol, gambling, or conventional financial services. Medical, diagnostics, and related business segments are fully permissible.

References:

  1. [SEC_10Q_2025Q3_IS] Abbott Laboratories Form 10-Q (quarter ended September 30, 2025) – Condensed Consolidated Statement of Earnings showing Interest (income) of $230m (9M25) and Net Sales of $32,869m. (filing, 2025-09-30) — Quantifies non-permissible interest income and the 9M25 revenue base used to derive ~0.70% NPIN; anchors the interest-income-only haram segment.
    Link
  2. [SEC_10Q_2025Q3_FV] Abbott Laboratories Form 10-Q (quarter ended September 30, 2025) – Fair value and investment tables showing long-term investment securities balances. (filing, 2025-09-30) — Supports the composition split by evidencing relatively small long-term investment balances vs. cash/short-term, implying most interest comes from short-term placements.
    Link
  3. [PR_3Q25] Abbott press release – Third-Quarter 2025 Results (Oct 15, 2025) (third_party_estimate, 2025-10-15) — Confirms 3Q25 and 9M25 sales context and presents the GAAP statement lines used alongside the 10-Q.
    Link
  4. [industry_alloc] Analyst allocation based on standard treasury operations for large-cap medtechs (industry_knowledge, 2025-12-26) — The minor allocation to miscellaneous interest-type items when exact disclosure is not provided; ensures composition sums to the segment estimate.
    Link

Final Shariah Verdict

The overall classification is COMPLIANT_WITH_PURIFICATION. Although non-permissible income exists at approximately 0.82% of total revenue, this is well below the 5% NPIN threshold, and hence the company passes the purity requirements of Shariah screening. The recommended purification ratio, applied to distributable income such as dividends, is 0.82%. There are no concerns relating to haram product involvement or other prohibitive activities.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • The sole source of haram income is non-operating interest income derived from conventional financial instruments, which is considered riba.
  • Business segments in diagnostics, medical devices, and research are deemed permissible and free from Shariah violations.
  • The debt level of 14.94% is within acceptable Shariah limits.
  • Cash and investment holdings amount to 2.79%, also within compliance limits.
  • Purification of dividends is mandatory based on calculated NPIN and haram revenue exposure.
  • No evidence of involvement in prohibited industries or activities, strengthening the compliance profile.
  • Dual-use assessment confirms a neutral stance with no adverse Shariah implications except for the isolated interest income.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. is approved for inclusion in Shariah-compliant portfolios subject to a purification of approximately 0.82% of dividends or distributable earnings to cleanse non-permissible income. Portfolio managers should continue monitoring any material movements in non-operating interest income or potential changes in business activities that may affect Shariah compliance. There are no red flags or material concerns that preclude holding this stock within Islamic funds. The company’s sound compliance with debt and liquidity thresholds, combined with its permissible primary business operations, make it a suitable investment with purification applied.

Shariah Compliance Report: Abbott Laboratories (ABT)

Executive Summary

Abbott Laboratories (ticker: ABT) has successfully passed the latest Shariah compliance screening as of the report date 15 October 2025. The company’s Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) ratio stands at a low 0.82%, well within the acceptable threshold of 5.0%. Key financial ratios including debt (7.12%) and cash plus investments (4.13%) are also compliant with Shariah limits. The overall Shariah verdict for Abbott Laboratories is COMPLIANT, with no significant haram revenue streams identified.

Company Overview

Exchange: NYSE

Country: United States

Reporting Period: FY 2025 (as of October 15, 2025)

Company Description: Abbott Laboratories is a global healthcare company specializing in medical devices, diagnostics, nutrition products, and branded generic pharmaceuticals. The company is widely recognized for its innovation in healthcare technology and commitment to improving patient outcomes worldwide.

Although the telecommunications sector is generally considered a dual-use/neutral infrastructure business with mostly permissible core services, certain ancillary services such as device financing, content, and payment services require further scrutiny.

Due to the absence of reliable estimates for non-compliant revenue and no detailed haram segments identified, a board review is advised to clarify any potential non-permissible revenue and to finalize the classification. Portfolio managers are advised to hold or avoid investing in this security pending the Shariah board's definitive review.

Exchange: NASDAQ

The company offers a wide range of mobile communication products and services to consumers and businesses across the United States. T-Mobile is known for its innovation in network technology and customer-centric approach.

Dual Use and Ancillary Business Lines: Telecommunications is a dual-use and neutral infrastructure business. The core services provided by T-Mobile US, Inc. are generally considered permissible. A dedicated Shariah board review is strongly recommended to resolve outstanding uncertainties.

  • The company's debt ratio of 52.36% surpasses the maximum allowable limit of 33%, which is a critical financial non-compliance issue.

Shariah Compliance Report: Broadcom Inc. (AVGO)

Header Snapshot

  • Ticker: AVGO
  • Company Name: Broadcom Inc.
  • Report Date: 2025-12-11
  • Sector: Semiconductors
  • Type of Security: Common Stock (COM)
  • Screening Status: FAIL
  • Final Shariah Classification: NON-COMPLIANT

Executive Summary

Broadcom Inc. has undergone a quantitative and qualitative Shariah screening as of the report date 2025-12-11. Despite all numeric financial ratios being within acceptable limits—debt ratio at 3.41%, cash and investments at 0.85%, and Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) at 0.00%—the overall screening status is FAIL, leading to a final verdict of NON-COMPLIANT. The key issue is the lack of sufficient data on haram revenue segments or a definitive breakdown that would confirm the absence of material non-permissible activities.

The company’s products, including semiconductors and AI infrastructure software, are considered dual-use technologies and are not inherently haram; customer end-use does not automatically render the revenue non-permissible.

Due to uncertainty and incomplete information, a Shariah board review is recommended before making final investment decisions.

Company Overview

Exchange: NASDAQ

Country: United States

Reporting Period: December 31, 2025

Company Description:

Broadcom Inc. is a global technology leader specializing in designing, developing, and supplying a broad range of semiconductor and infrastructure software solutions. The company caters to diverse markets including data centers, networking, broadband, wireless communications, and storage. Known for innovation and integrated solutions, Broadcom plays a critical role in enabling connectivity and digital transformation worldwide.

Business Segments Summary:

  • Semiconductor solutions for networking and broadband infrastructure
  • Enterprise storage and wireless semiconductor products
  • Infrastructure software and cybersecurity solutions
  • AI infrastructure software development

Quantitative Shariah Screening

Financial Ratio Value (%) Max Threshold (%) Compliance
Debt Ratio 3.41 33.00 PASS
Cash + Investments Ratio 0.85 33.00 PASS
Non-Permissible Income (NPIN) Ratio 0.00 5.00 PASS

Note: Despite all financial ratios being within standard limits, the screening status is FAIL due to qualitative and data completeness factors.

Non-Permissible Income & Haram Sector Assessment

Haram Revenue Composition:

Composition detail: N/A (not provided).

Comments on Haram Sectors:

The company’s products relate to dual-use/neutral technology; specifically, semiconductors and AI infrastructure software are not inherently haram. However, without clear and complete data on any material revenue from clearly prohibited sectors or activities, we are unable to conclusively verify full compliance. Customer use cases do not by themselves impact the permissibility of revenue recognition.

Red Flag Sectors: None identified.

References

N/A (no haram references provided in the memo).

Final Shariah Verdict

The company is classified as NON-COMPLIANT due to insufficient evidence and lack of an explicit haram revenue estimate. Although all numeric criteria (debt, NPIN, cash ratios) fall within acceptable limits, the absence of disclosed material non-permissible income percentages and detailed segment allocation necessitates caution. A Shariah board review is essential to confirm the absence of material impermissible income and validate the screening methodology.

Key Shariah Considerations

  • The reported NPIN ratio is 0.00%, implying no detected direct non-permissible income streams.
  • Debt and liquidity ratios are well within acceptable Shariah screening limits.
  • Dual-use technology classification indicates the company’s products are neutral, not inherently impermissible.
  • Absence of data on haram revenue composition limits confident classification.
  • Shariah compliance screening flagged the company's status as a “FAIL” due to missing haram revenue breakdown and incomplete disclosure.
  • Purification is currently unnecessary due to zero NPIN reported and lack of identifiable impermissible income.

Guidance for Portfolio Managers

Until further confirmation and detailed disclosure are obtained through a Shariah board review, it is advised to hold or avoid this security within Islamic investment portfolios. The borderline nature of the screening results and insufficient transparency warrant caution in approval for Shariah-compliant investing.

Portfolio managers should monitor any updates on segment disclosures or board decisions regarding the materiality of non-permissible income and consider re-screening once additional information becomes available.

It operates in multiple energy-related sectors including upstream oil extraction, downstream refining and chemicals, as well as energy technology development. The company serves customers worldwide with an extensive value chain connecting crude oil sources to end consumers.
